comment.author: 68439219@N06
comment._content:
Robert G. Fowler  Pilot   aircraft "Cole Flyer"  photo of aircraft used during Hearst $50,000 prize  transcontinental "race"  1911 -1912     Aircraft was purchased from Wright Brothers in Dayton, Ohio  Most likely taken at time of purchase.
Fowler began transcontinental flight , for second time, October 19,1911  from aviation grounds near Los Angeles. He arrived February 17,1912 , Pablo Beach , Florida.
This is the aircraft he used. Fowler never received a license from the Aero Club of America.

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Thanks so much Early Aviation for identifying the plane. We'll add this information to the record the next time we update.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Negative inscription: "9/5/11 no. 2" So this was before the race, identified elsewhere as being at the Wright Brothers, in Dayton, OH. (see next note). JJ Cole bought a Wright biplane and installed one of his automobile engines for the "Cole Flyer". Here's a little more about the Hearst race: In 1911, the Hearst Transcontinental Flight Derby sponsored a $50,000 prize to the first pilot who completed a transcontinental flight across the United States. The two most noted pilots who attempted this crossing were Calbraith (Cal) P. Rodgers, who took off in his biplane from Sheepshead, New York on September 17, 1911, and Robert C. Fowler, who attempted his flight from the opposite direction, taking off from San Francisco on August 12, 1911, with the hope of reaching Jacksonville, Florida." [Though it seems from Early Aviation's post that Fowler re-started in October) www.banninglibrarydistrict.org/banning/documents/airports... It's likely that the W.L. (William L. Colt) and "H.S."(Harry L.) Stratton pictured were the principals of New York's Colt-Stratton Company, an important auto distributor, and perhaps backers of Fowler's flight. They were in 1912 distributors of the Cole car, and Cole supplied the engine for the plane. books.google.com/books?id=Ibk-N4g_vBgC&pg=RA1-PA264&a... earlyaviators.com/efowler1.htm And J.J. Cole is therefore Joseph J. Cole, the early automaker who produced cars in Indianapolis, Indiana. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cole_Motor_Car_Company At that time, C.P. Henderson was Director and General Sales Manager of Cole Motors. books.google.com/books?id=UzMfAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA487&l... R.P. Henderson, and Homer C. Lathrop were also connected with Cole Motor Car. books.google.com/books?id=uEceAQAAMAAJ&q=lathrop+hend... L.S. French was a Cole executive as well. books.google.com/books?id=-LjhAAAAMAAJ&pg=PP3&lpg...

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: see also this Bain photo, apparently taken at the same session: Yet another photo from this day is at earlyaviators.com/ecolejj.htm and identifies Cole and Fowler in the plane in Dayton, OH. The unidentified man is William L. Colt, discussed above.

comment.author: 68439219@N06
comment._content:
Indianapolis,Indiana based Cole Motor Company  ( later became part of Cadillac) 
President J.J. Cole advanced $7,500 to Fowler.  (The Life and Times of Robert G. Fowler, Burden 1999)

comment.author: 68439219@N06
comment._content: ( in photo)   C. Fred Grundy , a Cole sales agent  from Los Angeles. Fowler's manager for the cross country journey.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content:
Thanks for filling that in.  The caption "C.W. Grundy" is wrong.  
There is a remote possibility that this Grundy is William Grundy, who along with C. Fred and J. Russell Grundy were partners in Grundy Motor Sales Co. in Los Angeles, but that seems unlikely as William is never connected with the flight in the sources I've looked at, and Fred was heavily involved.
That leaves  Nixon and Burns unidentified, but as everyone but as everyone but Fowler is affiliated with Cole Motor Co., this might have been a junket (to Dayton, if the early aviator site is correct) by the Cole group to meet with Fowler and see the plane.

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Thanks Early Aviation and artolog for the additional information about the people in this photograph.  We will add more details when we update.
